content:
What a wonderful project! Editing outdoor portraits in Lightroom can be a delightful process, and I'd be happy to share some tips to help you enhance your stunning captures. Here are some recommendations to get you started:

**1. Start with the basics:**
 Begin by adjusting the exposure, contrast, and white balance to set a solid foundation for your edit. Use the histogram to ensure your image isn't over or underexposed.

**2. Enhance the sky:**
 Outdoor portraits often feature a beautiful sky, so don't forget to give it some love! Adjust the Exposure, Contrast, and Saturation sliders in the Basic panel to make the sky more vibrant and appealing. You can also use the Gradient Filter tool to target the sky specifically.

**3. Work with the natural light:**
 Since you shot in a park, you probably had plenty of natural light to work with. Use the Shadows and Blacks sliders to recover detail in the shadows, and the Highlights slider to tame any blown-out areas. This will help balance the contrast and create a more natural look.

**4. Skin tone adjustments:**
 Portrait editing is all about enhancing your subjects' skin tones. Use the White Balance tool to adjust the color temperature to match the lighting conditions (e.g., daylight, shade, or overcast). Then, use the Skin Tone sliders (found in the HSL panel) to refine the skin tones, making them look more natural and pleasing.

**5. Local adjustments:**
 Use the Adjustment Brush or Gradient Filter to make targeted adjustments to specific areas of the image, such as:
	* Softening facial features or wrinkles
	* Enhancing eye color and brightness
	* Darkening or lightening specific areas of the image
	* Adding texture or detail to clothing or accessories

**6. Noise reduction and sharpening:**
 Since you shot with a Canon 80D, you may need to address some noise in the image, especially if you shot at higher ISOs. Use the Noise Reduction sliders in the Detail panel to reduce noise while preserving detail. Then, apply sharpening to enhance the overall image clarity.

**7. Crop and composition:**
 Don't forget to check the composition of your image. Crop the photo to focus attention on your subjects, and consider using the Transform tool to straighten any wonky horizons or lines.

**8. Presets and profiles:**
 Take advantage of Lightroom's built-in presets and profiles to speed up your editing process. You can also create your own custom presets to apply to similar images in the future.

**9. Non-destructive editing:**
 Remember that Lightroom is a non-destructive editor, so feel free to experiment and try different edits without worrying about damaging your original image.

**10. Take breaks and compare:**
 Editing can be a subjective process, so take breaks and come back to your image with fresh eyes. Compare your edited version to the original to ensure you're happy with the changes you've made.

By following these tips, you'll be well on your way to creating stunning, polished portraits that your cousins will love. Happy editing!
